Award.AwardTitle: Comparative Studies of Brain Size in Carnivores.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to identify factors that contribute to the evolution of large brains. The idea that the evolution of large brains is the result of selection pressures derived from living in complex social or physical environments is tested in carnivore member species. Here, the social brain hypothesis which proposes that the cognitive abilities resulting from social living are related to the evolution of large brains including the expansion of the frontal lobes is evaluated. In addition, other factors such as home range size, tree dwelling and food seeking styles are assessed. A primary goal of this project is to analyze carnivore skulls using computed tomography (CT) to create endocasts (a virtual brain). The analysis will evaluate the relationship between brain size including regional volumes and various measures of social, behavioral and environmental complexity both across and within species in 4 carnivore families. This data set is unique as most studies examine only a few species and often report on a small sample size of each species. These studies will identify the factors that contribute to the evolution of large brains in carnivores. By understanding the evolution of the brain, we might better understand how the human brain works and determine whether brains of particular non-human animals might serve as useful models for studies of the human brain.
This project will also provide neuroscience training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. The project will yield a unique brain data set including both a range of rarely studied species and a large sample size of selected species. Importantly, these data have significant potential to influence the field as a resource for other researchers interested in utilizing this carnivore brain data set in developing new ideas of brain evolution and function. The brain volume data will ultimately be accessible through an arrangement with the Comparative Mammalian Brain Collection Website (www.brainmuseum.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project utilized new technologies in digital imaging and 3D modeling techniques to study wild carnivores including some rare and endangered species to address questions regarding factors that drive brain evolution. These new technologies were applied to testing the social brain hypothesis in the Order Carnivora.  The social brain hypothesis proposes that brain size, particularly the frontal cortex, evolved in response to enhanced neural processing of social information.  Relative brain size is greater in species living in large social groups than in more solitary species. Primate studies provide ample support for the social brain hypothesis.  But if sociality acts as a selection pressure leading to the evolution of relatively large brains, a similar association should be found among social carnivore species.  We investigated the generalizability of the social brain hypothesis by measuring total and regional brain size in five carnivoran families.  Other behavioral and ecological factors thought to influence large brain size were also explored. We found relatively larger frontal cortex volumes in highly social carnivore species including the spotted hyena, lion, and coatimundi in comparison to their less social close relatives. Among these species, frontal cortex volumes corresponded to differing social life histories experienced by sex.  Female lions and coatimundi have larger frontal cortex volumes than their male counterpart while male spotted hyenas have more frontal cortex than females.  Also, cerebrum volumes including the frontal cortex are greater in pack living canids than in their less social relatives. But the same social effect was not found in the family Mustelidae.  For example, both wolverines and badgers, solitary species, possess significantly larger frontal cortex volumes than their more social relatives, otters. This result suggests that sociality is likely to be one of many factors that correspond to increased brain size and/or frontal cortex volume in carnivores. Large frontal cortex volume is found in solitary species, particularly honey badgers, wolverines and American badgers in Mustelidae and in the solitary leopard in comparison to either the cheetah or cougar in Felidae.  These species are all noted for problem solving capabilities and behavioral flexibility.  Relatively large brains including the frontal cortex might result from a number of behavioral and ecological factors in carnivoran families. Overall, our findings support the notion that within family comparisons reveal brain variations overlooked in broader taxonomic comparative studies.  These data on brain variations linked to behavioral factors in wild carnivoran species can be expected to inform conservation and management efforts.  The broader impact of this project included training of undergraduate and graduate students, creation of a carnivore brain database for the use of other researchers and enhanced scientific engagement with the public through a museum exhibit highlighting new technologies for studying the brain in wild carnivores.
